p: The exact nature of environmental conditions associated with climatic change that nonnatives will be able to capitalize on, when compared with native species, are poorly understood ( von Holle et al. 2010 ; Willis et al. 2010 ). While the role of species interactions is likely to be important in influencing range expansion by both native and nonnative species, few studies have focused on this ( Svenning et al. 2014 ; Jones and Gilbert 2016). Specifically, the role of soil microbes on species range expansion has not received as much attention as that for its role in plant community membership ( van Grunsven et al. 2007 ; Jones and Gilbert 2016). Our study demonstrates that soil microbiota negatively affect growth of one native and one nonnative species in habitats outside of their current range; however, one native species benefited more from soil microbes in the new range, and under warmer conditions, than the other native study species. Clearly more research is needed to elucidate the role of plantâ€“soil microbe interactions on native and nonnative species, when compared with other factors, to understand the potential for biotic interactions to govern range expansion in a rapidly changing world.
